Survei LSI: Pancasila Diterima Mayoritas Muslim Indonesia
04 Nov 2019, 02:33 by Egi Adyatama, Amirullah
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Hasil sigi Lembaga Survei Indonesia (LSI) menemukan bahwa Pancasila dan Undang-Undang Dasar 1945 sudah banyak diterima oleh mayoritas masyarakat muslim di Indonesia. Jumlahnya mencapai lebih dari 80 persen.
"86,5 persen responden muslim menilai Pancasila dan Undang-Undang Dasar yang sekarang adalah terbaik bagi kehidupan kita sebagai bangsa Indonesia," kata Direktur Eksekutif LSI Djayadi Hanan saat merilis hasil survei, di kawasan Wahid Hasyim, Jakarta Pusat, Ahad, 3 November 2019.
Survei ini melibatkan 1.550 responden yang dipilih secara acak. Periode survei adalah 8 sampai 17 September 2019, dengan margin of error 2,5 persen.
Djayadi mengatakan dari hasil survei itu, ada 4 persen responden yang merasa dasar negara bertentangan dengan Islam, dan 1,8 persen menganggapnya perlu diganti dengan undang-undang dasar lain.
Tren positif dukungan terhadap Pancasila dan UUD 45 ini terus meningkat, sejak tahun lalu sedikit sempat anjlok. Dari data LSI, pada 2016, angka dukungan masih ada di 82,3 persen. Angka ini melonjak pada 2017 menjadi 84,3 persen, sebelum sempat anjlok menjadi 83,2 pada 2018.
Temuan ini, menurut Djayadi, seharusnya bisa menjadi dasar bagi pemerintah untuk fokus pada penguatan Pancasila dan UUD, mengingat mayoritas umat muslim sudah final dengan dua pedoman tersebut. Ia agak menyayangkan langkah pemerintah saat ini yang terlalu fokus terhadap perlawanan kepada mereka yang anti-Pancasila dan UUD.
"Sekarang Pemerintahan Jokowi lebih fokus yang empat persen itu sehingga riak di masyarakat. Harusnya fokus saja di penguatan Pancasila dan UUD," ujar Djayadi.
Ia mencontohkan pemilihan sejumlah menteri di kabinet Indonesia Maju, oleh Presiden Joko Widodo. Beberapa nama seperti Menteri Agama Fachrul Razi yang mantan tentara dan Menteri Dalam Negeri Tito Karnavian yang eks Kapolri, seakan menegaskan bahwa pemerintah ingin menekan angka radikalisme.
Hal ini, dinilai Djayadi, justru seakan menegaskan langkah pemerintah yang terus menekan kebebasan sipil. Dari survei ini pula, kebebasan sipil dinilai semakin memburuk di era pemerintahan Jokowi selama lima tahun terakhir.
"Kabinet yang baru diumumkan juga seolah-olah mengkonfirmasi itu. Misalnya dipilihnya Menteri Agama yang berlatar belakang tentara, itu menimbulkan pertanyaan apa isu kebebasan sipil, toleransi, dan radikalisme apa akan dihadapi dengan pendekatan, bukan hanya lewat stabilitas, tapi juga keamanan," kata dia.

LSI Survey: Pancasila Received by Majority of Indonesian Muslims
Nov. 04, 2019, 02:33 by Egi Adyatama, Amirullah
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Results of the Indonesian Survey Institute (LSI) found that Pancasila and the 1945 Constitution have been widely accepted by the majority of Muslim communities in Indonesia. The amount reaches more than 80 percent.
"86.5 percent of Muslim respondents consider the Pancasila and the current Constitution to be the best for our lives as Indonesians," said LSI Executive Director Djayadi Hanan when releasing the survey results, in the Wahid Hasyim area, Central Jakarta, Sunday, November 3, 2019 .
This survey involved 1,550 respondents who were randomly selected. The survey period is 8 to 17 September 2019, with a margin of error of 2.5 percent.
Djayadi said from the results of the survey, there were 4 percent of respondents who felt the country's foundation was against Islam, and 1.8 percent thought it needed to be replaced by other constitutions.
The positive trend of support for the Pancasila and the 1945 Constitution has continued to increase, since last year there was a slight drop. From the LSI data, in 2016, the support figure is still at 82.3 percent. This figure jumped in 2017 to 84.3 percent, before it had dropped to 83.2 in 2018.
This finding, according to Djayadi, should be the basis for the government to focus on strengthening the Pancasila and the Constitution, bearing in mind that the majority of Muslims are final with these two guidelines. He regretted the current government's move to focus too much on resistance to those who are anti-Pancasila and the Constitution.
"Now the Jokowi government is focusing more on the four percent so that it is ripple in the community. It should just focus on strengthening Pancasila and the Constitution," said Djayadi.
He gave an example of the election of a number of ministers in the Indonesian cabinet Forward, by President Joko Widodo. Some names such as Minister of Religion Fachrul Razi who is a former soldier and Home Minister Tito Karnavian who is a former National Police Chief, seems to emphasize that the government wants to suppress the number of radicalism.
This, according to Djayadi, seems to confirm the government's move to continue to suppress civil liberties. From this survey also, civil liberties are considered increasingly deteriorating in the Jokowi era during the last five years.
"The newly announced cabinet also seems to confirm that. For example the election of a Minister of Religion with an army background, it raises the question of what issues of civil liberties, tolerance and radicalism will be faced with an approach, not only through stability, but also security," said he.
